Native Apps Are Dead

Dan Yoder 2011-06-05

I've often found it curious how often technologists - whose very job is to create disruptive innovation - evince a touching faith in the status quo. A recent example of this phenomena is the debate about native apps versus Web apps. Over the past fifteen years, Web apps have become increasingly powerful, to the point where, for some types of applications, they are nearly indistinguishable from conventional "native" applications. This is, at best, a silly debate, and, at worst, misleading.

Read more …

Facebook Is The New AOL

Dan Yoder 2010-10-25

Those CDs made handy compacts for the ladies.

Facebook "has already lost literally millions of us":facebook-dropoff around the world. "Millions more would leave":everyone-hates-facebook except that, at the moment, Facebook provides features they can't get anywhere else. As soon as there are decent alternatives, they will leave. Facebook, like MySpace and AOL and many others, will surely hang around for years after that point, but they'll be irrelevant. [facebook-dropoff]http://searchengineland.com/has-facebooks-active-user-growth-dropped-42036 [everyone-hates-facebook]http://gawker.com/5591650/everyone-uses-facebook-and-everyone-hates-it

The Death Ray And The Lean Startup

Dan Yoder 2010-07-28

First, a word from our sponsor, Goliathon, maker of awesome weaponry.

When I was but a fledgling entrepreneur, like most fledgling entrepreneurs, I became frustrated with the process of trying to raise money for my fledgling venture. Now, this was during the "dot-bomb" era, and so raising money was supposed to be easy. We also had an increasingly vocal contingent of curmudgeons, wondering why we couldn't just earn our money like everyone else, with hard work and everyday construction materials. We were pioneers, forging a new economy from bits and bytes and assembling entire companies by applying mass production to "value chains" where "capital formation" was no different than tightening bolts on a combustion engine!

Read more …

Why You Should Still Quit Facebook

Dan Yoder 2010-05-05

It's no exaggeration to say I've been overwhelmed by the response to my post on "why you should quit Facebook":/home/2010/4/26/top-ten-reasons-you-should-quit-facebook.html. To those of you who shared your stories about leaving, or took the time to clarify some of the reasons for doing so, thank you. Apparently, I was hardly alone in making the decision to quit, or at least seriously considering it. It has been nothing short of inspiring to read your comments and realize how many of you cared enough to take action, whether it was actually deleting your account or simply taking the time to share your thoughts.

Top Ten Reasons You Should Quit Facebook

Dan Yoder 2010-04-26

Let's all ban Facebook!

After some reflection, I've decided to delete my account on Facebook. I'd like to encourage you to "do the same":https://ssl.facebook.com/help/contact.php?show_form=delete_account&__a=3. This is part altruism and part selfish. The altruism part is that I think Facebook, as a company, is unethical. The selfish part is that I'd like my own social network to migrate away from Facebook so that I'm not missing anything. In any event, here's my "Top Ten" reasons for why you should join me and "many others":http://eu.techcrunch.com/2010/04/23/privacy-issues-google-engineers-leaving-facebook-in-droves/ and "delete your account":https://ssl.facebook.com/help/contact.php?show_form=delete_account&__a=3.

Geek Chic: Art Meets Technology At TEDx

Dan Yoder 2009-03-29

Cynicism is so easy.

It is easy to be a cynic. It is easy to say, _the hell with it_, and give up. But nothing really interesting ever gets done that way. And certainly part of what I love about TED -- and "Mindshare":mindshare and other events like it -- is that it celebrates perseverance. Some people don't get that. Was it cheesy as hell when Melissa Etheridge joined Muslim rock star "Salman Ahmad":salman, singing _ring the bells of change_, and everone was literally ringing these little bells? Hell, yeah it was. But when you back it up with an organizational behavior case study on building the "Large Hadron Collider":lhc or a talk by a "guy restoring sight to the blind":markh, well, you know what? I'll take the cheese all day long. Because, really, "it's a celebration":lhc-rap. [tedx]http://search.twitter.com/search?q=%23TEDxUSC [mindshare]http://mindshare.la/ [salman]http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salman_Ahmad [lhc]http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_Hadron_Collider

Read more …

The Ethics Of Innovation

Dan Yoder 2009-03-21

I grew up in Detroit, but I've got no love for American automakers. I think bailing them out is a waste of money. I want them to die and for Detroit to move on and find an industry who treats them better. Like Eminem, for example. Why do I hate them? Because they don't innovate.
